channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: Mandela Said to Be ‘Steadily Improving’ on 95th Birthday
item.description: After weeks battling critical illness, Nelson Mandela spent his 95th birthday in the hospital on Thursday, and South Africans across the country celebrated Mandela Day.
item.dc:creator: By LYDIA POLGREEN and ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: School children sang "Happy Birthday" to Nelson Mandela, the former president of South Africa, on Thursday in Soweto.

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: July 18
item.description: A man taking part in festivities on the final day of the Lord Jagannath chariot festival in Puri, Orissa.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: A man dressed as Hindu god Hanuman participating in festivities on the final day of the chariot festival of Lord Jagannath in Puri, Orissa.

item.title: Palestinians Call Kerry’s Formula for Talks Insufficient
item.description: The Palestinian leadership did not approve Secretary of State John Kerry’s plan for reviving peace talks with Israel, dulling hope for a breakthrough.
item.dc:creator: By KHALED ABU AKER and JODI RUDOREN

item.title: Listening Post: Israeli Envoy Shares Thoughts as He Prepares for a New Chapter
item.description: Michael B. Oren, who will leave his post this fall, says American and Israeli positions on the peace process dovetail and that the countries’ leaders have come to know each other “much better” during his tenure.
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER

item.title: Russian Court Convicts Opposition Leader
item.description: Aleksei A. Navalny, Russia’s most resonant opposition voice and a Moscow mayoral candidate, was sentenced to five years in prison on embezzlement charges.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:description: Aleksei A. Navalny in court on Thursday in Kirov, Russia.

item.title: India Ink: In Tamil Nadu, Nearly 150 Hospitalized After Eating School Lunch
item.description: Students from an all-girls government school in Neyveli suffered dizziness, vomiting and diarrhea soon after they were served a midday meal on Thursday.
item.dc:creator: By PAMPOSH RAINA and HARI KUMAR
item.media:description: Schoolchildren receiving a free midday meal at a school in Patna, Bihar on Thursday.

item.title: Germany Backs Greece’s Austerity Measures
item.description: Finance Minister Wolfgang Schäuble visited Athens and expressed “admiration” hours after Parliament approved a plan for laying off civil servants.
item.dc:creator: By NIKI KITSANTONIS

item.title: Insurgents Kill 8 Afghans Near U.S. Base
item.description: Eight Afghan men heading to work at an American base on Thursday morning were pulled from their car by insurgents and killed, officials said.
item.dc:creator: By MATTHEW ROSENBERG

item.title: Way of the World: Capitalism, but With a Little Heart
item.description: A lot of people, including many hard-driving capitalists, are trying to figure out how to retool the institutions of capitalism for our time so that pursuing social good is part of the business goal.
item.dc:creator: By CHRYSTIA FREELAND | REUTERS

item.title: Steam Detected at Damaged Fukushima Reactor
item.description: The operator of the ravaged nuclear plant in Japan stood ready Thursday to inject boric acid into the reactor if temperature or radiation levels rose.
item.dc:creator: By HIROKO TABUCHI

item.title: Retiring U.S. Envoy Faults Hong Kong and China on Snowden
item.description: The consul general, Stephen M. Young, suggested that Beijing intervened in Hong Kong affairs to let Edward J. Snowden flee the territory.
item.dc:creator: By GERRY MULLANY

item.title: India Ink: Electoral War Over Electricity Bills in Delhi
item.description: A new Indian political party is running an electoral campaign over electricity bills.
item.dc:creator: By SAI MANISH
item.media:description: A maze of overhead electric cables in New Delhi on Aug. 1, 2012.

item.title: Senate Panel Questions Nominee for U.N. Ambassador
item.description: Samantha Power appeared to face no serious obstacles to confirmation during a hearing of the Foreign Relations Committee.
item.dc:creator: By BRIAN KNOWLTON
item.media:description: Samantha Power appeared before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee on Wednesday.

item.title: British Agency Is Cleared of Illegal Data Gathering
item.description: The Government Communications Headquarters had been accused of accessing information from an American surveillance program.
item.dc:creator: By STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: In China and U.S., Mutual Distrust Grows, Study Finds
item.description: A Pew survey found that since 2011, China’s approval rating in the United States dropped to 37 percent and negative attitudes toward the United States among the Chinese rose to 53 percent.
item.dc:creator: By JANE PERLEZ

item.title: What Mandela Means to South Africans
item.description: Marcus Mabry of The Times talks to South Africans about what Nelson Mandela has meant to them, their country and the world.

item.title: North Korea Says Freighter Carried Legal Load of Arms
item.description: Breaking its silence on a rusty freighter seized by Panama and found to be carrying weapons for Cuba, North Korea demanded the ship’s release.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Attacks Have Immigrants Worried Again in South Africa
item.description: A wave of violence aimed at immigrants in poor black communities outside Cape Town has raised fears among residents, shopkeepers and advocates.
item.dc:creator: By RICK LYMAN
item.media:credit: Tomas Munita for The New York Times
item.media:description: Abdugadish Mohamed, left, a 28-year-old Somali, recently returned to the shop he runs outside Cape Town after it was looted in a wave of anti-immigrant violence.

item.title: Momentum Shifts in Syria, Bolstering Assad’s Position
item.description: Though his country is in shambles, President Bashar al-Assad now seems better positioned to hang on to power than he has been for most of Syria’s two-year civil war.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD
item.media:credit: Syrian Arab News Agency, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: President Bashar al-Assad's resilience suggests that he has carved out what amounts to a rump state in central Syria that is firmly backed by Russia, Iran and Hezbollah.

item.title: To Get Back on Its Feet, Italian Bank Gives Up Five Centuries of Control
item.description: Shareholders of Monte dei Paschi di Siena are expected to agree, under duress, to lift ownership restrictions on the bank, ending five centuries of cozy local control and political patronage.
item.category: Monte dei Paschi di Siena SpA
item.dc:creator: By GAIA PIANIGIANI and JACK EWING
item.media:description: Pageantry before the Palio, Siena’s medieval horse race, financed in part by the foundation controlling the Monte dei Paschi bank.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: The Drone That Killed My Grandson
item.description: Why was a 16-year-old American citizen killed by a drone strike in Yemen?
item.dc:creator: By NASSER al-AWLAKI

item.title: Greece Approves New Austerity Measures
item.description: The omnibus bill bundling together an overhaul of the civil service and a new tax code, along with other budget cuts, was endorsed by 153 lawmakers in the 300-seat House.
item.dc:creator: By NIKI KITSANTONIS

item.title: Perdasdefogu Journal: Celebrating the Elderly With a Nervous Eye on Italy’s Future
item.description: With older people in the Mediterranean living longer and longer lives, experts warn that Europe’s debt crisis is exacerbating a growing demographic crisis.
item.dc:creator: By RACHEL DONADIO

item.title: Amid Praise, Hope on Talks for Peace in Mideast
item.description: Arab League diplomats in Amman, Jordan, said Secretary of State John Kerry’s ideas were a “good basis” for restarting peace talks between Israel and the Palestinians.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON and JODI RUDOREN
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry arrived at a palace in Amman on Wednesday for a meeting with Jordan’s king, Abdullah II.

item.title: Challenges to Policies on Terror Are Halted
item.description: A federal appeals court held that the government could enforce a statute on the indefinite detention of terrorism suspects without trial, reversing a district judge’s decision to block the law.
item.dc:creator: By CHARLIE SAVAGE
